definitions.definition: a piece of clothing worn on the upper part of the body, made of light cloth, with sleeves and usually with a collar and buttons down the front

examples.text: He had a **shirt and tie** on.
She took a pen from her shirt pocket.
A man in a striped shirt sat alone in the corner.
He tucked his shirt into his pants.
He wears a crisp white shirt to the office every day.
I grabbed him by the collar of his shirt.
He was dressed in a loose fitting shirt and pants.
He pulled on his shirt and ran down to see what had happened.

definitions.definition: used to tell somebody not to get angry

examples.text: Keep your shirt on! It was only a joke.

definitions.definition: to bet all your money on somebody/something

examples.text: It's a good horse, but I wouldn't put my shirt on it.

definitions.definition: anything that somebody has, including the things they really need themselves, that somebody else takes from them or they are willing to give

examples.text: He was the type of person who would give you the shirt off his back.

wordOrigin: Old English scyrte, of Germanic origin; related to Old Norse skyrta (compare with skirt), Dutch schort, German Schürze ‘apron’, also to short; probably from a base meaning ‘short garment’.
